Against the rules for? Title say 22awg CAN, listing is 14awg

any particular reason why you are looking to use Shielded Cabling?

It’s not illegal as far as I know but for a shielded cable to be shielded, one end of it has to be GROUNDED. You can ground both ends as long as you can be 100% certain that you are not creating ground loop. If you don’t ground the shielded wire, then it’s not shielded at all and the un-connected wire then becomes an antannea. Potentially coupling any noise/interferences into the cable pair inside.

I still not quite agreed with FIRST not allowing teams to ground the chassis but I can see the reasoning.

I don’t know if you are using it for CAN or not. But iirc for CAN applications, you want the the two conductors twisted, and you want the wire to have a characteristic impedance of 120 ohms.

There is very little reason to use shielded wire unless you are somehow making a transformer out of your power and signal wires, in which case I have other questions.

The twisted nature of CAN helps mitigate interference on its own.

There is no rule stopping you from using any sized wire for signal down to and including 28AWG as per Rule R622 | FRCTools

This listing would be more than adequate, even without the shielding, for its mechanical properties (e.g., an intake)

Honestly wasn’t even looking for that but i really want it now. I was looking for generic 22awg for sensors and saw this and it got me thinking. It might be easier to thread through a dragon chain and could provide useful shielding just incase a wire gets clipped in riskier areas the team didn’t account and couldn’t iterate on before competition.

It also seems to keep wiring looking cleaner by seemingly having less wires.

This may seem nitty, but is an important electrical concept.

Robots are not grounded. To ground something is to electrically connect it to the earth.

Conductive components of a devices that are not specifically current carrying, can be electrically connected together, called bonding.

Often the bond in devices extends to the negative terminal, which links the potential plane of the bonded components to the electrical system. This is often done to create effective fault current clearing paths (among several reasons), generally a good thing. However, the device needs to be properly designed and built to those fault clearing requirements, which would burden teams to do, if it could be reliably done at all. But for us, this is moot as Rule 611 forbids it, as you note.
